pullrequest.title: Update the style of collapsible items

content.raw:
I see you went with the object name option, which is what we've been doing so far, so I think it's ok, especially since this button shouldn't change style.

I'll just mention the other approach I've been looking into, namely [Dynamic Properties and Stylesheets](https://wiki.qt.io/Dynamic_Properties_and_Stylesheets). It offers a way for the style to be changed programatically without hardcoding it in the C++ code and placing it on the qss file instead. This would allow, for example, applying the "warning" style to other buttons on demand, while giving downstream applications the flexibility to choose their own style.

I've been meaning to use this for the plot's `VariablePill`s, started here: 57118ef
content.html:
I see you went with the object name option, which is what we've been doing so far, so I think it's ok, especially since this button shouldn't change style.

I'll just mention the other approach I've been looking into, namely Dynamic Properties and Stylesheets. It offers a way for the style to be changed programatically without hardcoding it in the C++ code and placing it on the qss file instead. This would allow, for example, applying the "warning" style to other buttons on demand, while giving downstream applications the flexibility to choose their own style.

I've been meaning to use this for the plot's VariablePills, started here: 57118ef

pullrequest.title: Update the style of collapsible items

content.raw:
I believe this is a discussion for issue #16. 

I need to better collect my thoughts together and then I'll comment there, but just to give you an idea of where I am right now, after having looked at these widgets for a while and experimenting with a few things, I feel like there is a place for "panelled" widgets and a place for nested ones. GzWeb's menu for example features a combination of them. So I think we shouldn't try to look for a one-solution-fits-all approach and instead offer widgets for both options which can be combined for each use case.

So considering we do keep a nested option, I couldn't find anything in the material design spec which seemed appropriate for the kind of data we may be dealing with here, which is deeply nested.
content.html:
I believe this is a discussion for issue #16.

I need to better collect my thoughts together and then I'll comment there, but just to give you an idea of where I am right now, after having looked at these widgets for a while and experimenting with a few things, I feel like there is a place for "panelled" widgets and a place for nested ones. GzWeb's menu for example features a combination of them. So I think we shouldn't try to look for a one-solution-fits-all approach and instead offer widgets for both options which can be combined for each use case.

So considering we do keep a nested option, I couldn't find anything in the material design spec which seemed appropriate for the kind of data we may be dealing with here, which is deeply nested.

pullrequest.title: Update the style of collapsible items

content.raw:
The `CollapsibleWidget` was introduced as part of a mechanism to nest widgets into each other. If there is no nesting as proposed on issue #16, then the `CollapsibleWidget` is not needed.

Do you mind elaborating a bit on what's your final vision for the `TopicInterface` plugin and the `Grid3D` plugin? Will they keep sharing the same code, or will `MessageWidget` eventually move towards a panel navigation - which doesn't use collapsibles at all - while the `Grid3D` widget will end up composed of one-level-deep collapsibles?
content.html:
The CollapsibleWidget was introduced as part of a mechanism to nest widgets into each other. If there is no nesting as proposed on issue #16, then the CollapsibleWidget is not needed.

Do you mind elaborating a bit on what's your final vision for the TopicInterface plugin and the Grid3D plugin? Will they keep sharing the same code, or will MessageWidget eventually move towards a panel navigation - which doesn't use collapsibles at all - while the Grid3D widget will end up composed of one-level-deep collapsibles?

pullrequest.title: Update the style of collapsible items

content.raw:
I'm still working out a plan, and will come up with a design soon. I'm general nesting widgets leads to a confusing user experience, and is not scalable. I believe most UI do not needed a hierarchy, rather they support navigation through the hierarchy.

A collapsible widget is still useful, in the list context. Material design calls this expanding panels, or something similar.
content.html:
I'm still working out a plan, and will come up with a design soon. I'm general nesting widgets leads to a confusing user experience, and is not scalable. I believe most UI do not needed a hierarchy, rather they support navigation through the hierarchy.

A collapsible widget is still useful, in the list context. Material design calls this expanding panels, or something similar.

pullrequest.title: Update the style of collapsible items

content.raw: A tree view would be another approach, if we want to show multiple values at the same time.
content.html: A tree view would be another approach, if we want to show multiple values at the same time.

pullrequest.title: Update the style of collapsible items

content.raw:
I believe the current implementation of `MessageWidget` is essentially a tree view with properties:

* Items collapse
* Elements are indented according to their depth

I'm not saying there isn't room for improvement for the looks and interaction, but I *strongly* believe just throwing away all nested structures would be a mistake.

I'm taking a look at other pieces of software, for example [Unreal's world outliner](https://docs.unrealengine.com/latest/INT/Engine/UI/LevelEditor/SceneOutliner/#searchingtheworld), [Unity's inspectors](https://unity3d.com/ru/unity/whats-new/unity-5.1), [Blender's scene hierarchy](https://answers.unrealengine.com/storage/attachments/36841-root.png) - nested properties are everywhere and they serve a good purpose of allowing a high level quick introspection. By no means that should be the only interface, but I believe it is an essential one to the kind of software we're writing.
content.html:
I believe the current implementation of MessageWidget is essentially a tree view with properties:

  • Items collapse
  • Elements are indented according to their depth

I'm not saying there isn't room for improvement for the looks and interaction, but I strongly believe just throwing away all nested structures would be a mistake.

I'm taking a look at other pieces of software, for example Unreal's world outliner, Unity's inspectors, Blender's scene hierarchy - nested properties are everywhere and they serve a good purpose of allowing a high level quick introspection. By no means that should be the only interface, but I believe it is an essential one to the kind of software we're writing.

pullrequest.title: Update the style of collapsible items

content.raw: I would classify those examples as tree widgets, and I agree that they are useful. Or style of nested widgets I've never seen before. The key difference is that we are displaying arbitrary widgets within the hierarchy.
content.html: I would classify those examples as tree widgets, and I agree that they are useful. Or style of nested widgets I've never seen before. The key difference is that we are displaying arbitrary widgets within the hierarchy.
